items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Saturday evening at 8:00pm, and high tide on Sunday evening at 8:45pm. High water times are measured from Ilfracombe, times of high water will vary along the coast.

Coastal conditions are currently in a period of higher than average tide levels.

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.

We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue an update on Monday 15th August.

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level for Saturday evening at Ilfracombe is 5.05 mAOD, this is 0.08 metres above astronomical tide level. The forecast high tide level for Sunday evening at Ilfracombe is 5.09 mAOD, this is 0.15 metres above astronomical tide level.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
Flood alert remains in place for evening high tides on 14/08/2022 and 15/08/2022. Forecast high water is at 22:15 on Sunday 14/08/2022 with a level of 7.60 mAOD with force 3 south westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible one to two hours either side of the high tide. Flooding is possible along the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.   Tides will remain high on Monday evening 15/08/22 when high water is forecast to be 7.37 mAOD at 22:45hrs. We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and be careful along promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.
This message will be updated by 11:00 on Monday 15/08/22, or as the situation changes.

High tides are forecast to impact the estuary. Tides will be at their highest between 21:30 and 22:30 today, 14/08/22. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow. Predicted peaks:- Avonmouth Portbury 7.5m to 7.8m at 22:00 on 14/08, Newport 7.1m to 7.4m at 22:00 on 14/08. The morning tides for the 15/08 between 10:00 and 11:00 are forecast to be lower than the evening tides of the 14/08, and not reach flood alert levels. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please call 999 if in immediate danger and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 12:00 on 15/08/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from Old Hunstanton, to and including Cley
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 08:15am and 10:15am tomorrow morning, Monday 15th August.  We expect to see water on roads and paths to beaches and on the quays in Brancaster, Burnham Overy, Holkham, Wells and Blakeney.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.64 mAODN at 09:15, on Monday 15th August, which is 0.23m above tide tables, wind Force 3, easterly.  (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Monday 15th August.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from East Cley to Kelling Hard, including Salthouse
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 08:15am and 10:15am tomorrow morning, Monday 15th August.  We may see water on Beach Road at Cley, and Beach Road at Salthouse, and footpaths in the marshes may also become inaccessible.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.64 mAODN at 09:15, on Monday 15th August, which is 0.23m above tide tables, wind Force 3, easterly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Monday 15th August.

River levels are expected to be higher than usual at Fiddlers Ferry, Eastford Road, and Arpley Bridge as a result of a high tide tomorrow morning (15/08/22). Consequently, flooding of low lying land, roads and farmland, is expected between 02:45 am and 04:00 am on 15/08/22 in the following places: Fiddlers Ferry, between 02:45, and 03:30 am, Eastford Road, between 03:00, and 03:45 am, Arpley Bridge, between 03:15, and 04:00 am. It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge. Flood alerts may also be required for subsequent high tides. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels and will issue flood warnings if necessary. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  This message will be updated tomorrow at 11am (15/08/22), or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message: The weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.65mAOD at 17:30 on Sunday 14th August and 4.60mAOD at 06:15 on Monday 15th August.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is very low for this time of year at 5 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain very low for at least the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 12:15 on Monday 15th August, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high Spring tides and force 4 winds forecast for Sunday evening 14/08/2022 and Monday morning 15/08/2022. Water levels are expected to reach 6.58m AOD at peak tides on Sunday evening at 20:45pm, and 6.16m AOD at 09:00am on Monday 15/08/2022. Tide times are based upon Hinkley Point gauge. The Flood Alerts will be in force for 2 hours before and after these high water times.
Areas most at risk include the low-lying roads and paths along the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir.
We will continue to monitor levels closely
This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 15/08/2022, or as the situation changes

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 01:45am and 03:45am tomorrow morning, Monday 15th August.  Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray.  The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.7 mAODN at 02:45, on Monday 15th August, which is 0.21m above tide tables, wind Force 2, southerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Monday 15th August.
